episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin use Docker to create a runtime environment for a NodeJS web application. They cover the basics of having applications live in a container.
episodes.title: Building an Application with Docker
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.074 --> 00:00:01.289
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.289 --> 00:00:02.551
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.551 --> 00:00:08.226
[CROSSTALK]
[SOUND]

4
00:00:08.226 --> 00:00:12.388
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.388 --> 00:00:14.436
>> All right, greetings, everyone, and

6
00:00:14.436 --> 00:00:16.795
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.795 --> 00:00:19.808
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

8
00:00:19.808 --> 00:00:22.410
we are back with more of
our Intro to Docker series.

9
00:00:22.410 --> 00:00:26.640
And of course, joining us in the studio is
the person that knows all things Docker,

10
00:00:26.640 --> 00:00:28.220
our good friend, Mr Justin Dennison.

11
00:00:28.220 --> 00:00:30.480
Justin, my man, how goes it today?

12
00:00:30.480 --> 00:00:31.260
>> It goes well, Daniel.

13
00:00:31.260 --> 00:00:32.020
How are you today?

14
00:00:32.020 --> 00:00:33.240
>> Can't complain, thanks for asking.

15
00:00:33.240 --> 00:00:36.790
>> I feel like you're overselling
that all things Docker stuff.

16
00:00:36.790 --> 00:00:37.895
>> Just go with it, man.

17
00:00:37.895 --> 00:00:41.194
[LAUGH]
>> Mainly because it is very complex, but

18
00:00:41.194 --> 00:00:43.734
we have been wading our
way through Docker.

19
00:00:43.734 --> 00:00:47.740
And we actually have a great amount
of tools in our repertoire thus far.

20
00:00:47.740 --> 00:00:51.380
We're actually to a point to where
we can run containers, build images.

21
00:00:51.380 --> 00:00:54.814
But now how do I actually use
that technology that I've been

22
00:00:54.814 --> 00:00:57.293
working with to bundle up an application?

23
00:00:57.293 --> 00:01:02.150
Now there's a couple of things you should
know before we start down that road.

24
00:01:02.150 --> 00:01:04.350
I have chosen Node.js as our runtime,

25
00:01:04.350 --> 00:01:08.260
not because of any other
reason than I had to pick one.

26
00:01:08.260 --> 00:01:15.030
And well, it will work the same on Python,
Ruby, Go, Java, any JVM language.

27
00:01:15.030 --> 00:01:17.440
The setup's gonna be a little
bit different but abstractly,

28
00:01:17.440 --> 00:01:19.780
the same process is gonna occur.

29
00:01:19.780 --> 00:01:25.730
In addition to, well, this is for
a deployment type mindset.

30
00:01:25.730 --> 00:01:27.705
It is not for an active development cycle.

31
00:01:27.705 --> 00:01:29.395
If you're a developer there,

32
00:01:29.395 --> 00:01:33.170
I would actually mount the application
source code into the volume.

33
00:01:33.170 --> 00:01:36.343
And then set up a different
container that would be the runtime.

34
00:01:36.343 --> 00:01:40.530
This is going to be all bundled up,
send this off to Docker hub and

35
00:01:40.530 --> 00:01:43.840
then run this through continuous
integration to run my test.

36
00:01:43.840 --> 00:01:47.130
Also do an inspection for
security flaws and the such.

37
00:01:47.130 --> 00:01:51.060
So those are important things to keep
in your mind before we get started.

38
00:01:51.060 --> 00:01:54.310
But I think there's no better time
than now than let's take a look at

39
00:01:54.310 --> 00:01:55.540
how things are gonna play out.

40
00:01:55.540 --> 00:01:56.930
Let's take a look at my screen here.

41
00:01:56.930 --> 00:01:58.560
And so I'm on my desktop.

42
00:01:58.560 --> 00:02:01.990
And if I ls here,
I got this random folder.

43
00:02:01.990 --> 00:02:05.114
But I also have nodeapp version 1,
2 and 3.

44
00:02:05.114 --> 00:02:10.270
Now if I was actually on a development
cycle, I would not keep multiple copies.

45
00:02:10.270 --> 00:02:13.717
I would use some version control
system like Git or Mercurial.

46
00:02:13.717 --> 00:02:17.383
But to keep things transparent and
a little easier to follow,

47
00:02:17.383 --> 00:02:21.770
I've kept different copies of
the application in its different states.

48
00:02:22.920 --> 00:02:27.490
In addition to, we're gonna assume
that these are all finally done.

49
00:02:27.490 --> 00:02:28.360
Now what does that mean?

50
00:02:28.360 --> 00:02:30.620
That means that you can bundle them up and
deploy them.

51
00:02:31.930 --> 00:02:35.358
And we're going to work
through these one by one.

52
00:02:35.358 --> 00:02:37.810
You gotta definitely finish
out the folder name there.

53
00:02:37.810 --> 00:02:38.620
>> It does help.

54
00:02:38.620 --> 00:02:39.630
>> It does help.

55
00:02:39.630 --> 00:02:43.480
And notice that all I
have in here is index.js.

56
00:02:43.480 --> 00:02:45.980
Well, you don't have to
know anything about Node.

57
00:02:45.980 --> 00:02:50.570
All the source code will be
available to you in the show notes.

58
00:02:50.570 --> 00:02:54.261
But there will be a liittle bit
of programming here and there.

59
00:02:54.261 --> 00:02:57.616
You don't have to know how to do it
other than this little tiny segments.

60
00:02:57.616 --> 00:03:00.463
Most of it will be pre-done for you.

61
00:03:00.463 --> 00:03:06.223
And well, the whole goal is to focus on
bundling this up into a Docker image so

62
00:03:06.223 --> 00:03:11.458
we can ship that off to Docker Hub and
then deploy that as a container.

63
00:03:11.458 --> 00:03:13.600
We're gonna start very simply though.

64
00:03:13.600 --> 00:03:15.820
So let's take a look at index.js.

65
00:03:15.820 --> 00:03:21.350
And all it's going to say is
console.log('Running on NodeJS!.');.

66
00:03:21.350 --> 00:03:22.360
Okay, well what does that mean?

67
00:03:22.360 --> 00:03:23.990
I don't know anything about Node.

68
00:03:23.990 --> 00:03:29.646
Well, if I just run this on my computer,
I have Node installed on my computer.

69
00:03:29.646 --> 00:03:32.392
It just prints it out running on Node.js.

70
00:03:32.392 --> 00:03:35.957
Well, that's great, but
if you can install it on your computer,

71
00:03:35.957 --> 00:03:38.959
why would we ever even care
about building a container?

72
00:03:40.610 --> 00:03:44.786
Well, the fact being is every time I
wanted to deploy this application,

73
00:03:44.786 --> 00:03:49.030
I would need to make sure that I provision
some Linux server, either a VM or

74
00:03:49.030 --> 00:03:51.848
an EC2 instance, or
something of that nature.

75
00:03:51.848 --> 00:03:55.764
Do all the setup and
make sure Node's installed, and

76
00:03:55.764 --> 00:03:58.470
then actually set up to run, right?

77
00:03:58.470 --> 00:04:02.530
I have to expose it on port 80 in order
to make it available on the Internet.

78
00:04:02.530 --> 00:04:03.860
And it's just a lot of work.

79
00:04:03.860 --> 00:04:05.700
And this manual maintenance, this set up,

80
00:04:05.700 --> 00:04:09.100
this tendency kind of
aggregation is a nightmare.

81
00:04:09.100 --> 00:04:12.310
As someone who has actually
done that from time to time,

82
00:04:12.310 --> 00:04:15.510
setting up Apache servers and
stuff, it is not fun time.

83
00:04:15.510 --> 00:04:18.550
So I like the Docker ecosystem
because it makes this easy.

84
00:04:18.550 --> 00:04:21.350
You do it one time and you're done.

85
00:04:21.350 --> 00:04:24.956
Now what we need to do is build
a Dockerfile that takes this and

86
00:04:24.956 --> 00:04:26.732
puts it kind of all together.

87
00:04:26.732 --> 00:04:29.099
We're gonna start simply and
make sure that it runs and

88
00:04:29.099 --> 00:04:30.660
look through a few commands.

89
00:04:30.660 --> 00:04:35.840
But I think there's no better time than
now to start building up that Dockerfile.

90
00:04:35.840 --> 00:04:38.090
So you can use any text editor you want.

91
00:04:38.090 --> 00:04:42.432
I'm using Vim, or VI is available to you.

92
00:04:42.432 --> 00:04:45.142
Nano or Adam or any of those,
but this is just so

93
00:04:45.142 --> 00:04:48.840
you don't get a little motion
sick as I swipe between screens.

94
00:04:49.870 --> 00:04:52.790
And it slows me down a little bit and
keeps me honest.

95
00:04:54.100 --> 00:04:55.260
So what am I gonna do?

96
00:04:55.260 --> 00:04:59.430
Well, I know from my experience
that I know a great deal.

97
00:04:59.430 --> 00:05:03.070
Well, when I say a great deal,
I know a fair amount

98
00:05:03.070 --> 00:05:07.280
about Debian-based Linux distributions,
that well,

99
00:05:07.280 --> 00:05:11.950
I can provision a great deal of servers
and I can get Node running fairly quickly.

100
00:05:11.950 --> 00:05:17.040
I will forewarn you, on Docker Hub, there
is a Node.js platform already available.

101
00:05:17.040 --> 00:05:18.662
I can say from Node.js, and

102
00:05:18.662 --> 00:05:23.800
it will pull a Docker image that already
has Node installed and everything.

103
00:05:23.800 --> 00:05:26.881
I'm gonna go through this to show you,
well, what if I'm not running or

104
00:05:26.881 --> 00:05:29.473
something that it already has
that available to me, right?

105
00:05:29.473 --> 00:05:33.408
Maybe it's some weird JVM language
that keeps cropping up and

106
00:05:33.408 --> 00:05:35.764
I'm building this application in.

107
00:05:35.764 --> 00:05:37.453
I need to know how to do this.

108
00:05:37.453 --> 00:05:39.870
So we're starting from a base Linux.

109
00:05:39.870 --> 00:05:43.660
And then we're gonna build up our runtimes
so our application will be there.

110
00:05:43.660 --> 00:05:45.550
All right, so starting with Ubuntu,

111
00:05:45.550 --> 00:05:49.880
that's my base image,
I'm going to issue a few run commands.

112
00:05:49.880 --> 00:05:53.940
And the first one is apt get update -y.

113
00:05:53.940 --> 00:05:56.070
Make sure you put that -y in
there because if you don't,

114
00:05:56.070 --> 00:05:57.230
it's gonna say, are you sure?

115
00:05:57.230 --> 00:05:59.311
And then your build's gonna fail.

116
00:05:59.311 --> 00:06:04.031
And then I'm going to
run apt get install if I

117
00:06:04.031 --> 00:06:08.505
can spell apt get appropriately, curl.

118
00:06:08.505 --> 00:06:10.843
Also gonna issue a -y.

119
00:06:10.843 --> 00:06:14.239
Okay, well-
>> Kind of a silent install thing you got

120
00:06:14.239 --> 00:06:14.852
going on.

121
00:06:14.852 --> 00:06:16.434
>> Right.

122
00:06:16.434 --> 00:06:21.311
>> Typically if you're doing anything with
aptitude, you're definitely gonna have

123
00:06:21.311 --> 00:06:26.185
a -y or a -f or something, where there's
no prompts that require you to interact,

124
00:06:26.185 --> 00:06:28.580
because the Docker build will fail.

125
00:06:28.580 --> 00:06:30.070
And we've seen that in previous episodes.

126
00:06:30.070 --> 00:06:31.400
But this is a reminder,

127
00:06:31.400 --> 00:06:35.280
cuz this was a point of frustration when
I first started playing around with this.

128
00:06:35.280 --> 00:06:39.950
Now with that said, notice that I'm
keeping these on separate lines.

129
00:06:39.950 --> 00:06:44.473
When I'm done, I would probably move
this all into a single run command, or

130
00:06:44.473 --> 00:06:46.888
at least start pushing these together.

131
00:06:46.888 --> 00:06:50.190
But I'm utilizing
the cache as separate runs.

132
00:06:50.190 --> 00:06:52.958
That way,
if I need to change this line, well,

133
00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.606
then that's the only
line that has to rerun.

134
00:06:55.606 --> 00:06:59.230
Well, and anything after that
because the cache has changed.

135
00:06:59.230 --> 00:07:02.910
All right, so now that I have curl, well,
I'm gonna type some things here and

136
00:07:02.910 --> 00:07:04.950
then we're gonna talk
about what they're doing.

137
00:07:06.020 --> 00:07:09.103
So I'm gonna run

138
00:07:09.103 --> 00:07:13.728
curl -sl, https://

139
00:07:13.728 --> 00:07:21.665
deb.nodesource.com/setup_6.x.

140
00:07:21.665 --> 00:07:23.720
And then I'm gonna pipe that to bash.

141
00:07:25.210 --> 00:07:30.589
And finally, well, finally for
now, finally for now,

142
00:07:30.589 --> 00:07:38.350
we are going to say, apt-get install
nodejs and add a -y to that as well.

143
00:07:38.350 --> 00:07:40.670
All right, we're gonna test this.

144
00:07:40.670 --> 00:07:43.210
I'm not gonna move any further with
actually building an application for

145
00:07:43.210 --> 00:07:45.900
now because we wanna make
sure that this builds.

146
00:07:45.900 --> 00:07:47.888
And this is a great way to
think about Docker images.

147
00:07:47.888 --> 00:07:52.960
If your runtime doesn't exist, let's say
that Node didn't exist on Docker Hub,

148
00:07:52.960 --> 00:07:57.027
well, I could build this image,
save it to my Docker Hub account.

149
00:07:57.027 --> 00:08:00.972
And then use it as the base image,
for another Docker file.

150
00:08:00.972 --> 00:08:06.359
And I can then inherit this setup that I'm
creating for the respective [CROSSTALK].

151
00:08:06.359 --> 00:08:09.087
>> So no reinventing the wheel once
you've got the, just like you like it,

152
00:08:09.087 --> 00:08:10.352
you bake that cookie perfectly.

153
00:08:10.352 --> 00:08:13.237
You can redo the recipe over and
over again with just a copy and

154
00:08:13.237 --> 00:08:14.266
paste kind of thing.

155
00:08:14.266 --> 00:08:17.159
>> Right, and
actually it even gets simpler than that.

156
00:08:17.159 --> 00:08:21.950
This FROM command here,
becomes instead of FROM ubuntu,

157
00:08:21.950 --> 00:08:25.905
it becomes in this case, justindevpro/
>> Right.

158
00:08:25.905 --> 00:08:27.940
>> Node, so they're not gonna
use that as a base image.

159
00:08:27.940 --> 00:08:29.260
So we're gonna see that.

160
00:08:29.260 --> 00:08:30.399
One final thought here.

161
00:08:30.399 --> 00:08:34.974
In recent versions, apt-get,
you can actually shorten that to apt for

162
00:08:34.974 --> 00:08:36.474
the Aptitude manager,

163
00:08:36.474 --> 00:08:41.661
you will get some weird errors about not
being TTY compliant and all these things.

164
00:08:41.661 --> 00:08:45.598
So I tend to use with apt-get, even though
when I'm messing around in Linux I make

165
00:08:45.598 --> 00:08:49.095
sure that I command to apt,
just because I don't like typing apt-get.

166
00:08:49.095 --> 00:08:52.047
But in Dockerfiles you
get little warnings about

167
00:08:52.047 --> 00:08:54.786
not having appropriate outputs sometimes.

168
00:08:54.786 --> 00:08:55.878
So leave it there.

169
00:08:55.878 --> 00:08:58.037
So let's go ahead and save this.

170
00:08:58.037 --> 00:09:02.596
I did not mean to get out of it, though.

171
00:09:02.596 --> 00:09:04.776
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I did saved it.

172
00:09:04.776 --> 00:09:05.418
>> Old habits, right?

173
00:09:05.418 --> 00:09:05.983
>> Old habits.

174
00:09:05.983 --> 00:09:09.330
But this one command
here was kind of weird.

175
00:09:09.330 --> 00:09:12.229
Like where would I,
how would I know this, right?

176
00:09:12.229 --> 00:09:15.541
How do I know to type this,
Justin, you just made that up.

177
00:09:15.541 --> 00:09:16.403
No, I didn't.

178
00:09:16.403 --> 00:09:20.361
I had to look this up because this is
where my node run time comes from.

179
00:09:20.361 --> 00:09:22.954
And I was working on Ubuntu.

180
00:09:22.954 --> 00:09:25.909
So let's go take a look
where did that come from.

181
00:09:25.909 --> 00:09:31.683
And let's go to Google and
type, node.js ubuntu.

182
00:09:31.683 --> 00:09:35.709
Now this could of easily been Fedora,
or Red Hat or Cent.

183
00:09:35.709 --> 00:09:39.518
And Installing Node js
via package manager.

184
00:09:39.518 --> 00:09:45.030
And here is the list of all
these distributions here.

185
00:09:45.030 --> 00:09:48.367
Arch, Debian based,
Enterprise Linux, Fedora.

186
00:09:48.367 --> 00:09:51.743
Some of these I don't know, and even
Windows, yeah, which is kind of weird,

187
00:09:51.743 --> 00:09:54.249
cuz I don't think of Windows
as having package managers,

188
00:09:54.249 --> 00:09:56.213
but it does have a couple
of third party ones.

189
00:09:56.213 --> 00:09:57.373
>> Better late than never, right?

190
00:09:57.373 --> 00:09:58.451
>> That is exactly right.

191
00:09:58.451 --> 00:10:01.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I'm gonna stay with the Debian.

192
00:10:01.160 --> 00:10:06.366
And notice, here's that command,
kinda, kinda.

193
00:10:06.366 --> 00:10:10.514
Here's that command here that
I've put into my Dockerfile.

194
00:10:10.514 --> 00:10:12.937
And what this does is it grab a setup.

195
00:10:12.937 --> 00:10:18.272
It adds a key, it adds it to your
list of repositories for apt-get.

196
00:10:18.272 --> 00:10:22.630
And then I have the ability to
apt-get install In your Dockerfile,

197
00:10:22.630 --> 00:10:24.928
you could use the package manager.

198
00:10:24.928 --> 00:10:29.975
You could also use wget or
cURL to download the binary, and

199
00:10:29.975 --> 00:10:34.816
then you use your package manager,
whether BEM or DNF or

200
00:10:34.816 --> 00:10:40.074
apt or whatever to install from
that Debian package, okay?

201
00:10:40.074 --> 00:10:43.413
And I think misspoke there,
they're a little bit different,

202
00:10:43.413 --> 00:10:47.828
not quite the package manager there but
like a, your Debian packaging resources.

203
00:10:47.828 --> 00:10:53.108
I don't recommend that because if you
go to rebuild this, like let's say that

204
00:10:53.108 --> 00:10:58.080
node has an update, this update will
stay current with node version six.

205
00:10:58.080 --> 00:11:02.318
Otherwise I'm gonna have to change
the URL for the actual binary, so

206
00:11:02.318 --> 00:11:06.423
I tend to use package managers in
my Docker build files where I can.

207
00:11:06.423 --> 00:11:11.485
So if we notice here though, Daniel,
do you see anything that's a little

208
00:11:11.485 --> 00:11:15.991
odd from this command that's
highlighted to this command here?

209
00:11:15.991 --> 00:11:19.745
>> Yeah,
you're definitely missing that sudo -E.

210
00:11:19.745 --> 00:11:21.573
>> Yeah, sudo -E's not there.

211
00:11:21.573 --> 00:11:23.823
>> Yeah.
>> So, and then a sudo here, and

212
00:11:23.823 --> 00:11:25.051
just as a reminder,

213
00:11:25.051 --> 00:11:29.551
when you're doing a Docker build you
already have elevated privileges.

214
00:11:29.551 --> 00:11:32.369
So if you go to look, right?

215
00:11:32.369 --> 00:11:36.439
I needed to add this node source
to the Debian package manager.

216
00:11:36.439 --> 00:11:39.389
And then I have to get
sudo apt-get installed.

217
00:11:39.389 --> 00:11:43.161
Okay, well, if you type sudo,
your Docker build will fail.

218
00:11:43.161 --> 00:11:45.463
So keep that in mind, be very careful.

219
00:11:45.463 --> 00:11:49.590
You're already elevated at what
you can do inside of a Dockerfile.

220
00:11:49.590 --> 00:11:52.705
Don't need sudo,
just run it and let it rip.

221
00:11:52.705 --> 00:11:55.632
>> Think Node Js with Pink and
a little addendum there on their website,

222
00:11:55.632 --> 00:11:59.231
letting you know if you're doing this in
Docker, forget that whole sudo business.

223
00:11:59.231 --> 00:12:01.684
>> Well, maybe they just make
an assumption that, well,

224
00:12:01.684 --> 00:12:05.188
if you're doing anything in Docker,
you don't need the sudo business at all.

225
00:12:05.188 --> 00:12:06.696
>> Yeah.
>> And that's for

226

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee breakdown the structure of IP addresses. They identify the distinction of host versus network bits and explain why it is important to understand the structure. You will also see them explain a high-level understanding of subnetting.
episodes.title: Describe Basic Network Addressing

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike begin their look at SQL injection. They discuss what SQL injection is and where the vulnerability occurs. They demonstrate performing a SQL injection through a form on a web page as well as by injecting a command in a URL.
episodes.title: SQL Injection

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take a look at Virtual Private Clouds(VPCs) in Amazon Web Services. They start with VPC basics, (what is it and where is it used), and then move into more specific topics like Subnets, Route Tables, Elastic IPs, Endpoints and Peering.
episodes.title: Virtual Private Cloud

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take time to look at the state of computer forensics in today's world. Here they build your foundational knowledge and vocabulary necessary for the CHFI exam and our series. Specific topics covered includes: Defining computer forensics and the objectives of computer forensics.
episodes.title: Computer Forensics in Todays World

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne take a few moments to explain input text and special characters in Word 2016. Here they talk about adding basic text like letters, numbers, and symbols like \*/%/@. They also explain the difference between backspace and delete, paragraphs and line-breaks, and tabs. Finally, they explain the Show/Hide button's function and even give you some history about where the different character sets come from.
episodes.title: Input Text and Special Characters

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne introduce Word 2016 users to image basics.  They discuss different image formats that can be used in Word.  Vonne describes image resolution and why its important for the user.  She demonstrates how to insert a local image, an online image and a modified image created in Microsoft Pain.
episodes.title: Images Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee introduce offline files.  Cherokee describes this as an option to consider when  low bandwidth considerations are in play or when the internet connection back to the network folders is not available.  She shows how to configure it and explains the options  you must consider before implementation.
episodes.title: Configure File and Share Access

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes take you through commonly used Windows Control Panel utilities. Specific tools looked at includes: Display settings, User Accounts, Folder Options, System, Windows Firewall, and Power Options.
episodes.title: Control Panel Utilities Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike attempt to solidify your Kali skills by applying them to real-world type scenarios. Here they will scan a server and use Kali along with pen testing methodology to exploit 2 known vulnerabilities with rlogin and vsftpd.
episodes.title: Test Your Skills sample

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover basic log messages from boot-up, system log, SYSLOG, system log rotation, additional maintenance of logs, remote system logs, RSYSLOG, making logs permanent, SystemD Jounal, storing logs as secured binary so they can't be altered, how logging differs on various OS, persistent storage, JournalCTL command, JournalD as a replacement for SYSLOG, filtering for priority and filtering for time.
episodes.title: Configuring System Logging
